pico.title: Privacy-Preserving Distribution of High-Resolution Urban Satellite and Aerial Imagery: A Scoping Review
pico.population: High-resolution (sub-meter to 30cm) satellite and aerial imagery of urban areas containing potentially identifiable features including vehicles, building details, rooftop installations, activity patterns, construction sites, and in some cases individuals, acquired by commercial satellite operators, aerial survey companies, and municipal authorities
pico.intervention: Privacy-preserving techniques for urban imagery distribution including automated anonymization (object detection and blurring, synthetic replacement, generative inpainting), access control frameworks (tiered licensing, user vetting, purpose limitation), resolution degradation protocols, temporal aggregation, and derivative product approaches (vector extraction, indices only)
pico.comparison: Different anonymization techniques compared against each other; anonymized vs. restricted-access vs. resolution-limited distribution models; automated vs. manual review processes
pico.outcome: Utility for urban analysis tasks (building detection, change monitoring, infrastructure mapping, urban growth modeling, disaster damage assessment), privacy protection effectiveness (re-identification prevention, sensitive facility protection), processing overhead and scalability, compliance with privacy regulations, and commercial viability of different distribution models
pico.research_question: For high-resolution satellite and aerial imagery of urban areas, how do different anonymization and access control approaches compare in enabling urban analytics applications while protecting identifiable features and complying with privacy regulations?
pico.rationale: Commercial satellite imagery now achieves 30cm resolution where individual people, vehicles, and detailed building features are clearly visible. Urban planners, emergency responders, researchers, and smart city applications increasingly demand this high-resolution data. However, privacy regulations (GDPR, state-level US laws) increasingly apply to imagery containing identifiable individuals or enabling inference of personal activities. The tension between analytical utility and privacy protection requires evidence-based approaches to imagery distribution that the market currently lacks.

sub_questions.title: Automated Anonymization Effectiveness
sub_questions.population: Sub-meter satellite and aerial imagery of urban areas
sub_questions.intervention: Deep learning-based object detection and anonymization (vehicle blurring, face detection, license plate masking, rooftop pool/installation blurring)
sub_questions.comparison: Different detection models (YOLO, Faster R-CNN, specialized urban models); blurring vs. synthetic replacement vs. removal
sub_questions.outcome: Detection recall for sensitive objects, false positive rate, impact on downstream urban analysis tasks, processing speed and cost
sub_questions.research_question: How effective are automated deep learning approaches at detecting and anonymizing privacy-sensitive features in high-resolution urban imagery, and what residual risks remain?

sub_questions.title: Resolution-Utility Trade-offs
sub_questions.population: High-resolution urban imagery used for building detection, change monitoring, and infrastructure mapping
sub_questions.comparison: Original resolution vs. degraded versions across multiple urban analysis tasks
sub_questions.outcome: Task-specific accuracy degradation curves, minimum resolution requirements for different applications, privacy protection at each resolution level
sub_questions.research_question: What is the relationship between spatial resolution reduction and utility loss for common urban remote sensing tasks, and at what resolution does meaningful privacy protection begin?

sub_questions.title: Access Control Model Effectiveness
sub_questions.population: Organizations distributing high-resolution urban imagery (commercial providers, government agencies, research data centers)
sub_questions.intervention: Tiered access control systems (public/research/government tiers, purpose-based licensing, user vetting procedures)
sub_questions.comparison: Open distribution, single-tier restricted access, multi-tier systems
sub_questions.outcome: Compliance verification effectiveness, data misuse incidents, administrative burden, researcher access friction, commercial revenue impact
sub_questions.research_question: How do different access control models for high-resolution urban imagery compare in preventing misuse while enabling legitimate research and operational applications?

stakeholders: Real estate and property analytics companies
